pages.text: Bronze is the next metal tier up from copper. Luckily, it's not that hard to get. Bronze is an  $(item)alloy$(), meaning that it's made up of different metals. To make an alloy, you need to put the metals in in such a way that their units follow the percentages in the $(thing)alloy recipe$() you want.
$(item)Bismuth Bronze:$()$(2br)$(thing)Copper:$() 50-65%$(br)$(thing)Zinc:$() 20-30%$(br)$(thing)Bismuth:$() 10-20%$(2br)Remember that Zinc is Sphalerite, and copper has 3 ore forms.

$(item)Black Bronze:$()$(2br)$(thing)Copper:$() 50-70%$(br)$(thing)Silver:$() 10-25%$(br)$(thing)Gold:$() 10-25%$(2br)When making an alloy, you want the percentages to add up to 100, so that you'll have a full ingot. As long as they fall within the bounds, these percentages may vary. Do the math before you smelt!

$(item)Bronze$()$(2br)$(thing)Copper:$() 88-92%$(br)$(thing)Tin:$() 8-12%$(2br)Remember that Cassiterite is Tin. For example, 1 cassiterite nugget and 9 native copper nuggets in a pit kiln would give you an ingot's worth of molten bronze!
